label: Letter to Anna R. Frost from Frederick Grimke, August 30, 1861
description: A letter from Frederick Grimke to Anna R. Frost focusing on war news and politics, the usurping of power by the Federal government, postal relations between the Confederacy and the USA, and France and Great Britain's failure to formally recognize the Southern Confederacy.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Chillicothe 30 Aug. 1861.
Dear Anne

I have just finished a fifth num-
ber of [reflections?] on the present state of public affairs, and take 
up my pen to answer your of the 5th You observe therefore th-
at I have departed from the resolution I had [found?], not to
take up my pen, until the horizon had cleared up, and a bright-
er prospect had opened before us. I found that I could not shake
off the anxieties, which incessantly haunted me, in any other
way than by giving free utterance to my feelings, and Presumed
my pen in order to afford a relic if to my mind. It is very I-
[illegible], that the democratic party in the North, have not been si-
lenced; nor have they joined the [mouths?] of the other party; for I
find that my articles, have been hailed by the former with un-
bounded satisfaction. The editor of "The Crisis" published at Co-
lumbus closes a long notice of them, by saying "thrilling in their
warnings to the American people; whose spirit of independence
is not yet dead in them they will arouse the Nation to the [illegible], and
agonizing dangers which beset them" It is evident also from the
fact, that four editors of newspapers in [illegible] been a [illegible] to
be arraigned before the courts, for giving utterance to 

[End page 1]

[illegible] so many instances of bold violations of the law, that
I shall not be surprised, if the administration [leafs?] over many
more [illegible], in order to vent their [illegible] against the South.
They must be very much alarmed by the [vent?], and consternation
at [Manassa?], when they [illegible] to make war upon private
correspondence.-The agent here, of Adams' express informed me that it
was their practice to carry letters to some Post Office in the [illegible]
states, and there [illegible] them, and yet the informed that
none other than [in?] States stamp was necessary. Now I cannot
understand how a letter placed in a Post Office in the [illegible]
States should reach the place of distinction un-
less a stamp of the Confederate States was [assigned?] to it. I can
understand why I should have viewed a letter from Mon-
tague lately, which had only on U States stamp. because it
was deposited in P Office in Kentucky; for Kentucky
has not seceded. Perhaps there may be some understand-
ing between the Express, and the Southern government,
which this consents to sacrifice the revenue which would
be derived from its P Office rather than place any impediment
in the way of private correspondence [illegible], it is in striking
contrast with the course pursued by the U States.
The placard which you enclosed me, [brother?] strong by of revo-
lutionary times: it reminds one of the atrocious proceedings
during the French Revolution, when Robespierre, Dauton,
and Sautene made the scaffold flow with blood, and
spared neither sex, nor age. As [illegible], I have heard of
nothing being done, it is to be preserved that the [illegible]
who uttered such horrid threats, against their fellow ci-
tizens, failed in courage, and that the plan of [presuming?]
indictments has been adopted. But as we have no sedi-
tion law, I do not see how they can possibly succeed in the
new plan they have fallen upon. The constitution secures
freedom of speech, and of the press, and I am sure that
the savage threats which proceed from the press of the
republican party, are much more calculated to lead
to breaches of the peace, than the warnings where have
contained in the democratic [illegible] papers.

[End page 2]

I state and the matter too strongly, when I said Great Britain,
and France had recognized the independence of the
Southern Confederacy. They have made no formal recog-
nition of its independence. Nevertheless they have given
the most unmistakable proof, that they consider it so,
and that it is their fixed determination to make a
formal recognition before very long. Great numbers of
agents from both France and England, have visited
the southern states during all this summer, for the
purpose of contracting for the purchase of the incom-
ing crop of cotton. If they are the private agents of the
great [illegible] factoring establishment in those coun-
tries, there must be a perfect understanding between
them and the government, and if as has been said, they
are the direct agents of those governments, the dye
is already cast, and an open recognition is certain. All
the leading newspapers, in England, of both the Tory
and Whig party, are loud in their commendations
of President David government, and are not spar-
ing in their reproaches of President Lincolns. I have
before me, extracts from no less than five of the [most?]
influential english newspapers, all of which are
openly in favor of the southern republic. It is very
much the same with the French newspapers, they
exhibit the same tone, and hold the same language.
The present prime minister of England, Lord Pal-
merston has been distingusihed during the whole of
this public life, for alarming towards republics. In
the civil wars of Spain, Portugal and Switzerland,
he invariably sided with the oppressed party, and
in the war between Hungary, and Austria, he showed
the same disposition; while on the other hand Lord
Derby, the [illegible] of the Tory party, and prime minister
just before Palmerston has disclosed himself decidedly
in favor of the Confederate States.
Remember me to Mary Anna.

Ever yours affy. 
F. Grimke

[End page 3]

[To] Anna R Frost
North Orange
New Jersey

[Postmarked] Chillicothe
Aug 31 1831

[End page 4]
